Environment Configuration¶

Loading Varibles Into Terminal Session¶

You will want to export the environment variables defined in the /env/environment.env file into your current terminal session while using and developing the application. You can source the scripts/util/env-vars.sh shell script to load these variables,

source ./scripts/util/env-vars.sh

If this script is provided an argument, it will search for an .env file within the /env/ with the name supplied, i.e.,

source ./scripts/util/env-vars.sh container

will attempt to export the /env/container.env variables into your session. If it does not find this file, it will copy the /env/.sample.env into a new file with that name and ask you configure it before executing the script again. If no argument is provided, it will search for /env/.env and perform the same checks.

Environment Variables¶

See the comments in the /env/.sample.env for more information on each variable. Most of the defaults shouldn’t need changed except for ALPHA_VANTAGE_KEY, IEX_KEY and QUANDL_KEY.

Service Configuration¶

  1. PRICE_MANAGER: defines the service manager in charge of retrieving asset price historical data.

  2. STAT_MANAGER: defines the service manager in charge of retrieving economic statistics historical data.

  3. DIV_MANAGER: defines the service manager in charge of retrieving dividend historical data.

  4. ALPHA_VANTAGE_URL: URL used to query AlphaVantage for asset price histories.

  5. ALPHA_VANTAGE_CRYPTO_META_URL: URL used to query to AlphaVantage for metadata on crypto market.

  6. ALPHA_VANTAGE_KEY: API key required to authenticate AlphaVantage queries.

  7. QUANDL_URL: URL used to query Quandl for economic statistics histories.

  8. QUANDL_META_URL: URL used to query Quandl for metadata on economic statistics.

  9. QUANDL_KEY: API key required to authenticate Quandl queries.

  10. IEX_URL: URL used to query IEX for dividend histories.

  11. IEX_KEY: API key required to authenticate IEX queries.

Algorithm Configuration¶

  1. ITO_STEPS: The number of segments into which the integration domain is divided during the calculation of Ito Integrals.

  2. FRONTIER_STEPS: Number of data points calculated in a portfolio’s efficient frontier. Each data point consists of a (return, volatility)-tuple for a specific allocation of assets.

  3. MA_1: Number of days in the first Moving Average period. Defaults to 20 if not provided.

  4. MA_2: Number of days in the second Moving Average period. Defaults to 60 if not provided.

  5. MA_3: Number of days in the third Moving Average period. Defaulst to 100 if not provided.

  6. RISK_FREE: values = (“3-Month”, “5-Year”, “10-Year”, “30-Year”). The US Treasury yield used as a proxy for the risk free rate when valuing securities and equities.

  7. MARKET_PROXY: Recommend values: (“SPY”, “DIA”, “QQQ”). Defines the equity ticker symbol used by the application as a proxy for market return. While the recommended values are preferred, there is nothing preventing more obscure ticker symbols from being used the MARKET. GME, for instance. ;)

CLI Configuration¶

  1. LOG_LEVEL: values = (“info”, “debug”, “verbose”). Verbose is extremely verbose. The result of every single calculation within the application will be outputted.

  2. FILE_EXT: values = (“json”). Determines in what format cached price, statistic and dividend histories are saved. Currently only supports JSON. In the future, will support XML and CSV.

GUI Configuration¶

  1. GUI_WIDTH: Defines the width in pixels of the application’s root PyQt widget. Defaults to 800 if not provided.

  2. GUI_HEIGHT: Defines the height in pixels of the application’s root PyQt widget. Defaults to 800 if not provided.

Application Server Configuration¶

  1. SECRET_KEY: The secret used by Django to sign requests.

  2. APP_ENV: Informs the application which environment is it running in, i.e. either local or container

  3. APP_PORT: Configures the port on which the WSGI application runs.

  4. DEBUG: Configures Django’s debug mode.

  5. DJANGO_SUPERUSER_EMAIL:

  6. DJANGO_SUPERUSER_USERNAME:

  7. DJANGO_SUPERUSER_PASSWORD:

Database Configuration¶

  • Note: If APP_ENV not in ['local', 'container'], then the server will default to a SQLite database and the following environment variables will not affect the application.

  1. POSTGRES_HOST: should be set equal to the name of the postgres service defined in the docker-compose.yml; the default is datasource

  2. POSTGRES_PORT:

  3. POSTGRES_DB:

  4. POSTGRES_USER:

  5. POSTGRES_PASSWORD:

  6. PGDATA:

Container Configuration¶

  1. APP_IMG_NAME: Image name of the application created during the Docker build.

  2. APP_TAG_NAME: Tag applied to the application image created during the Docker build.

  3. APP_CONTAINER_NAME: Container name applied to the running application image when it is spun up.

  4. SCRAPPER_ENABLED: If set to True, the container will scrap price histories from the external services for storage in the postgres instance orchestrated with the application.
